Award.AwardTitle: IGERT--Resilience and Adaptive Governance in Stressed Watersheds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project is a multidisciplinary graduate training program in resilience and adaptive governance in stressed watersheds at the University of Nebraska - Lincoln. Resolving complex water issues requires the best and clearest scientific information from interdisciplinary and integrative science. This program will train the next generation of natural resource scientists, managers, and policymakers by increasing scientific understanding of how resilience - the ability to withstand multiple stresses without losing critical structure and function - is generated in complex systems of people and nature. It will provide cross-disciplinary academic and experiential training for a diverse group of doctoral graduate students in natural, social and computational sciences, and provide opportunities for minority students. Broader impacts include training in the complex interactions of ecological and societal systems affecting water management and in the use of sophisticated mathematical and computational tools for decision support. IGERT doctoral students will receive academic training in resilience and adaptive management and will participate in externships and workshops that expose them to real-world applications that transfer knowledge in a way that is useful to policymakers. Local, state and federal agencies will help shape curricula in natural science, policy and law by developing student research externships. Students will benefit from an international experience comparing compromised watersheds in the Great Plains of the United States to similarly challenged watersheds in Europe. This program will assist in fundamentally changing academic culture by coalescing students and faculty from natural science, social science, computational science and law around a common goal: the responsible management of over-appropriated watersheds. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Much of the world is experiencing conflicts over finite water resources. In the United States, water shortages have generated legal and policy battles over watershed management and the competing stakeholder needs for water in agriculture, drinking, industry, recreation, and wildlife protection. Water depletion and pollution results in the death of millions of people each year. Water shortages are actually only a portion of the management challenge. Flood damages continue to mount despite enormous investments in river engineering designed to shunt water as quickly as possible downstream.

 Water conflicts are complex and managing water resources requires an integrative framework. Adaptive governance and adaptive management are integrative approaches that treat policy and management as experiments to determine and decrease uncertainties, and to identify thresholds for the successful management of complex systems of people and nature. For adaptive governance and adaptive management to be successful, explicit training is needed for future social and natural resource scientists, managers, and policymakers in both adaptive management and resilience theory. Resilience theory focuses on the capability of complex systems of people and nature to absorb disturbance without losing structure and function. For example, the greater the resilience of a system, the less likely it is to cross a threshold and reorganize into a state that is qualitatively different and may provide fewer beneficial environmental services than it had previously. Because the state of a system following a transition is unpredictable, it is usually in humanity’s best interest to maintain and enhance resilience and avoid traversing critical thresholds.

 An understanding of resilience theory and effective use of resilience’s implications for research, water management practice, and policy, requires inter- and trans-disciplinary training in computational, social, and natural sciences. Such training enables natural resource scientists, managers, and policymakers to better respond to the challenges presented by increasing demands for diminishing resources and the need to maintain and build resilience in stressed watersheds. To help address this critical need, the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL), along with its government, industry, and international partners, established an IGERT program in Resilience and Adaptive Governance in Stressed Watersheds to serve as the innovative foundation for an interdisciplinary graduate program.

Our IGERT provided cross-disciplinary training for 21 Ph.D. students from natural, computational, and social sciences. Training goals were to develop an understanding of the complex and intertwined ecological and societal systems involved in managing water resources in the 21st century. In addition to exposing Trainees to substantive and interdisciplinary academic knowledge, the program exposed Trainees to real-world policy applications.

 Our IGERT trainees were from UNL’s schools of natural resources and biological sciences, and departments of computer science and engineering, geosciences, political science, sociology, and agricultural economics. The program provided approximately three years of support per Trainee. Trainees were exposed to, and trained in, the areas of resilience theory and adaptive management through an interdisciplinary curriculum, and through externships with NGO, industry, and government partners responsible for adaptive management and recovery of the Platte River and other Great Plains watersheds. Trainees were exposed to the adaptive management of watersheds in Eastern Europe through support from the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis in Vienna, Austria.
